title: Cash-crisis health group paid two temps £220 a day
content:
A PUBLIC health bodymaking huge cuts has refused to reveal details about two temporary members of staff who were each paid £220 a day. 
 
North East Essex Clinical Commissioning Group, which “buys” health services in Colchester and Tendring, had to disclose “off-payroll engagements” in its financial report. 
 
It revealed two staff members were paid about £52,000 pro rota on contracts lasting between six and 12 months. 
 
The report does not say how many days they worked, or how much they were paid. 
 
A spokesman for the group said: “Two members of staff from an independent organisation were employed on an interim basis. 
 
“One led the development and delivery of our Care Closer to Home programme, and the other was covering a role that was responsible for the contract management of mental health services. 
 
“Due to contractual agreements, we are not in a position to reveal howmuch they were paid per day.” 
 
The Care Closer to Home programme involves community visits to prevent unnecessary hospital admissions. 
 
The commissioning group has already undertaken a number of cost-saving measures, including cutting NHSfunded vasectomies and female sterilisation. 
 
It also stopped free prescriptions of gluten-free food and scrapped elective surgery for some smokers and obese patients. 
 
It wants to stop most free IVF treatment, although there is a three-month consultation on this.

Earlier this month it also announced it wants to scrap free hearing aids for patients with minimal hearing loss to save £150,000 a year. 
 
Over the next three years, £42.6million savings will be needed.
